title: 115_hr4498
content: The Act may be cited as the "No Arms Sales to Iran Act". It includes findings related to arms sales. The "No Arms Sales to Iran Act" highlights findings regarding Iran's ballistic missile tests, regional destabilization efforts, and proposed arms transfers despite ongoing aggression. The "No Arms Sales to Iran Act" emphasizes that arms transfers to Iran would destabilize the region and undermine regional peace objectives. The Secretary of State should engage diplomatically to prevent such transfers. The "No Arms Sales to Iran Act" requires the Secretary of State to report on covered activities or transfers annually. Additionally, it prohibits military assistance to countries engaging in arms transfers and activities with Iran. The "No Arms Sales to Iran Act" prohibits military assistance and arms exports to countries engaging in covered activities or transfers with Iran. The President can waive these prohibitions on a case-by-case basis. The "No Arms Sales to Iran Act" prohibits military assistance and arms exports to countries engaging in covered activities or transfers with Iran, unless the President determines it is in the national interest of the United States to do so. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "appropriate congressional committees" refer to specific committees in the House of Representatives and Senate. The term "covered transfer or activity" pertains to arms transfers or activities with Iran outlined in certain paragraphs of a UN resolution. The term "Joint comprehensive plan of action" is also defined. The term "Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action" refers to the agreement made in Vienna on July 14, 2015, by Iran and six other countries, along with the EU, regarding Iran's nuclear program. It was transmitted to Congress on July 19, 2015, as per the Iran Nuclear Agreement Review Act of 2015.
